head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fire Department Relents On Locker Policy

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Fire Department Relents On Locker Policy

body.head.byline: By RAY RIVERA; Compiled by John Sullivan

abstract.p: New York City Fire Dept amends policy prohibiting firefighters from placing anything on outside of their lockers other than name and locker number; Uniformed Firefighters Assn complained that department was clearing locker doors of flags and Mass cards commerating fallen colleagues and threatened to sue; ban is now limited to sexually explicit, discriminatory or obscene materials; photo (M)

block.p: The New York Fire Department bowed to its largest union yesterday by amending a policy that prohibited firefighters from having anything but their names and locker numbers on the outside of their lockers. The policy was intended to keep racist and pornographic material out of the city's firehouses after a string of complaints. But the Uniformed Firefighters Association said the ban had been carried too far when unit commanders began clearing locker doors of flag stickers, Mass cards commemorating fallen colleagues, and other items. The union threatened to sue if the policy was not changed by today. Late yesterday, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, above, issued new regulations spelling out prohibited material, including sexually explicit photographs and any discriminatory or obscene material.
